items.title: Charlottetown woman with postpartum depression pleads guilty to killing daughter
items.summary_auto: A Charlottetown woman accused of killing her infant daughter has pleaded guilty to infanticide instead of the first-degree murder charge that was originally laid against her — a charge she is eligible for because of her mental state at the time.

items.title: Truck with travelling Ontario ballet’s entire Nutcracker set stolen
items.summary_auto: A ballet company on an Ontario-wide tour of The Nutcracker says someone stole the moving truck storing its “irreplaceable” sets and backdrops.

items.title: Truck with travelling Ontario ballet’s entire Nutcracker set stolen in GTA
items.summary_auto: A ballet company on an Ontario-wide tour of The Nutcracker says someone stole the moving truck storing its “irreplaceable” sets and backdrops.

items.title: Criminal cases against ex-FBI director Comey, Letitia James dismissed in blow to Trump administration
N.L. asks Deloitte to carry out review after 'incorrect' citations found in provincial health plan
Why are ER wait times so long?
items.summary_auto: Lengthy wait times have become a reality for patients trying to get into emergency rooms across the country. Marketplace investigates why the system is in crisis and how it’s driving more Canadians to walk out of ERs without ever being seen.

items.title: U.S. Pentagon investigating Democrat senator for video urging troops to defy ‘illegal orders’
items.summary_auto: The Pentagon says that it is investigating Democratic Sen. Mark Kelly of Arizona for possible breaches of military law after Kelly joined a handful of other lawmakers in a video that called for U.S. troops to refuse unlawful orders.

items.title: Calgary airport resumes operations after pausing flights as snowstorm hits city
Most Canadians cherish holiday gatherings despite dinner table debates, poll finds
items.summary_auto:
The upcoming holiday gatherings with relatives may feel ripe for conflicts over politics, relationships, and social
issues, but an online survey suggests a majority of Canadians still feel it's important to spend time with loved ones.

items.title: Joni Mitchell and Nelly Furtado to receive special honours at the 2026 Juno Awards
items.summary_auto: The first round of performers for the March ceremony in Hamilton were also announced.

items.title: She started a diaper bank out of her apartment, and was swamped with need
NBA head coach Chauncey Billups enters not guilty plea in illegal gambling case
items.summary_auto: Portland Trail Blazers coach and basketball Hall of Famer Chauncey Billups pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges he profited from rigged poker games involving several Mafia figures and at least one other former NBA player.

items.title: Donald Glover says he had a stroke last year
items.summary_auto: Donald Glover is opening up about a recent health scare that forced him to cancel his tour last year.

items.title: Constitutional challenge set to begin for B.C. activists who tested, sold hard drugs
items.summary_auto: A constitutional challenge by the founders of the Drug User Liberation Front is expected to begin Monday at the B.C. Supreme Court, with the activists arguing that criminalizing alternatives to the unregulated drug supply forces users to rely on deadly street drugs.

items.title: This rubber duck museum in a U.S. border town has lost business. Now it's moving to B.C.
items.summary_auto: Quirky Point Roberts-based Rubber Duck Museum is coming to Tsawwassen Mills mall in B.C. after increasing tariffs and decreasing tourism have made business in the U.S. exclave unsustainable.

items.title: Jimmy Cliff, reggae legend and star of The Harder They Come, dead at 81
items.summary_auto: Jimmy Cliff, who was a presence at the birth of modern Jamaican music and helped spread the influence of reggae around the world through his albums and starring role in The Harder They Come, has died. He was 81.

items.title: Experts call for free nasal naloxone across B.C., as pilot project outcome uncertain
items.summary_auto: While the province has explored wider distribution of the spray for free as a pilot program, Health Minister Josie Osborne says it has not completed an evaluation of the program initially set to be completed late this summer.

items.title: Dashcams aren’t allowed during Ontario road tests, but this Sudbury teen thinks they should be
items.summary_auto: A Sudbury teen says dashcams should be allowed during Ontario driving exams because they can protect drivers from being found liable in case of a crash.

items.title: A look at rental affordability across Canada shows N.S. is the worst
items.summary_auto: A new tool created by real estate firm Turner Drake & Partners blends multiple indicators of housing markets across Canada to assign scores to be used for comparison. It shows the financial burden on renters in Nova Scotia is greater than in any other province.

items.title: Lobster fishermen raise safety concerns before start of new season
items.summary_auto: With the most lucrative lobster fishery in the country set to open, some fishermen are looking for fresh approaches to make sure opening day gets off to a safer start. CBC’s Michael Gorman has the story.

items.title: Pressure on renters higher in N.S. than any other province, analysis finds
items.summary_auto: A new tool created by real estate firm Turner Drake & Partners blends multiple indicators of housing markets across Canada to assign scores to be used for comparison. It shows the financial burden on renters in Nova Scotia is greater than in any other province.

items.title: After her study on trans athletes lost funding in the U.S., this Canadian researcher is starting over
items.summary_auto: Canadian-born researcher Joanna Harper has been studying the ways hormone therapy makes a difference in transgender athletes' performance for nearly two decades. Her most recent study, which she was working on in the United States, lost its funding bringing her back to Canada.

items.title: Suicide bombers kill 3 at Pakistan paramilitary headquarters
items.summary_auto: Three suicide bombers targeted the headquarters of a Pakistani paramilitary force on Monday, killing three personnel and wounding at least five, authorities said.

items.title: Digital cadavers, pairing med students with teens: Health-care co-op programs are targeting high schoolers
items.summary_auto: Co-op programs in health-care spaces regularly enlist post-secondary students, but some are skewing younger to target high schoolers. The hope is to spark interest in a broader pool of teens, especially those from under-represented groups, and get more of them thinking about Canada's health-care system.

items.title: Uh oh. The dreaded polar vortex may be making an appearance very soon
items.summary_auto: In 2014, the term “polar vortex” burst on the scene across Canada and the U.S. as temperatures plunged. In some places, it was colder than it was on Mars. Well, get ready to hear more about it.

items.title: Booking.com cancelled woman's $4K hotel reservation, then offered her same rooms for $17K
items.summary_auto: When an Ontario woman made a $4,300 hotel reservation on Booking.com, she never expected the website would cancel it, then offer her the same accommodations for quadruple the price. A digital rights lawyer says such cases show how weak consumer protections allow online platforms to shift risk and costs onto travellers.

items.title: How the provincial takeover of an Ontario school board 13 years ago played out
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s new law meant to make it easier for the province to take control of school boards it deems “fall off the rails,” isn’t a new thing in the Windsor-area.

items.title: ‘It’s complicated’: What happens when the family cottage gets divided by 8?
items.summary_auto: Over half a century of family memories and tradition are tied to a property in Prince Edward County for Jennifer Lester Mulridge's extended family. But family dynamics and ownership costs make inheritance challenging, as Lester Mulridge explains in this video made in collaboration with CBC Ottawa's Creator Network.

items.title: Younger-skewing co-op programs aim to spark teen interest in health care
items.summary_auto: Co-op programs in health-care spaces regularly enlist post-secondary students, but some are skewing younger to target high schoolers. The hope is to spark interest in a broader pool of teens, especially those from under-represented groups, and get more of them thinking about Canada's health-care system.

items.title: Bear encounters on the rise in B.C. community where grizzlies attacked school group, residents say
items.summary_auto: As B.C. conservation officers continued to search for the three grizzlies involved in Thursday’s attack on an elementary school group in Bella Coola, residents say the incident reflects years of rising bear encounters in the remote Central Coast community.

items.title: #TheMoment grocery stores held dance parties in Winnipeg and Calgary
items.summary_auto: Joanne Roberts tells The National about the moment she attended a party in a grocery store that brought her closer to her community.
